review: This story offers a refreshing and unique take on romance by blending a book-within-a-book concept. The enemies-to-lovers trope and slow-burn romance captivated me throughout. The narrative evoked a spectrum of emotions, making me laugh, cry, and forge a deep connection with the characters.

In the heart of NYU's writing program, Rosie, a sweet and hopeful romantic, finds herself paired with Aiden, a snobbish and arrogant classmate. Their relationship is characterized by playful bickering and sharp banter, making their interactions both entertaining and tumultuous. As they navigate a forced collaboration on a book project, the tension deepens, leaving me eager to see whether they'll reconcile their differences.

The writing is delightfully quirky, making it a perfect fit for a romance novel. The dialogue, especially Aiden's poignant struggle with pretending to hate Rosie, is both emotionally charged and memorable.
conclusion: This novel is a delightful and emotionally rich romance that combines a unique premise with well-developed characters and a compelling enemies-to-lovers dynamic. It’s a must-read for anyone who enjoys heartfelt, slow-burn love stories.

  - The narrative evoked a wide range of emotions, making me laugh, cry, and feel deeply connected to the characters.  

- **Characters:**  
  - Rosie is a sweet, hopeless romantic attending NYU’s writing program, where her main genre is romance.  
  - Aiden, her classmate, is snobby, rude, and arrogant, especially toward Rosie.  
  - Their dynamic is filled with bickering and banter, which makes their interactions both entertaining and disruptive.  
  - The forced collaboration on a book project adds tension and depth to their relationship, leaving me wondering if they’ll overcome their differences.  

- **Writing Style and Tone:**  
  - The writing is quirky and perfectly suited for a romance novel.  
  - The dialogue, particularly the quote about Aiden’s struggle with pretending to hate Rosie, is emotionally charged and memorable.  

- **Overall Enjoyment:**  
  - I loved everything about this book and am eager to read more from the author.  
  - The story kept me engaged from start to finish, and I highly recommend it to fans of romance.  

**Conclusion:**  
This novel is a delightful and emotionally rich romance that combines a unique premise with well-developed characters and a compelling enemies-to-lovers dynamic. It’s a must-read for anyone who enjoys heartfelt, slow-burn love stories.  

**Rating Scores:**  
(No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.)

review: Aiden and Rosie, both MFA students at NYU, embody a captivating rivalry: Aiden, a melancholic litfic writer, and Rosie, an idealistic romance author. Their witty banter is both hilarious and engaging, perfectly capturing the grumpy litfic boy x sunshine romance girl trope. Their opposites-attract chemistry makes the story a delightful read.

The rivals-to-lovers trope shines in this book, making it one of my favorites of 2024—and perhaps of all time. The addition of fake dating and numerous acts of service heighten the romantic tension and emotional payoff.

The banter between Aiden and Rosie is delightful, keeping me giggling under my blanket late into the night. Their forced collaboration on a book creates an incredible tension that enhances the excitement of their relationship.
conclusion: This book is a standout rivals-to-lovers story with phenomenal banter, incredible tension, and a beautifully executed opposites-attract dynamic. Aiden and Rosie’s journey from rivals to lovers is both hilarious and heartwarming, making it one of my favorite reads of the year. I cannot recommend it enough!

  - Aiden and Rosie are both in the MFA program at NYU, with Aiden being a sad boy litfic writer and Rosie an idealistic romance writer. Their dynamic as rivals is electric, and their bickering is both hilarious and engaging.  
  - The "grumpy litfic boy x sunshine romance girl" trope is executed perfectly, with their opposites-attract chemistry making the story incredibly enjoyable.  

- **Banter and Tension:**  
  - The banter between Aiden and Rosie is phenomenal, leaving me giggling under my blanket late into the night.  
  - When they’re forced to co-write a book, the tension between them is out of this world, adding a layer of excitement and anticipation to their relationship.  

- **Narrative Style and POV:**  
  - While not a traditional dual POV, we get Aiden’s thoughts and feelings about Rosie through their co-written book, which adds depth to his character and his obsession with her.  
  - The "it’s always been you" trope is beautifully executed, and Aiden falling first is a highlight that resonates deeply.  

- **Tropes and Themes:**  
  - The rivals-to-lovers trope is one of the best I’ve read, making this one of my favorite books of 2024 and possibly of all time.  
  - The story includes a dash of fake dating and plenty of acts of service, which enhance the romantic tension and emotional payoff.  

**Conclusion:**  
This book is a standout rivals-to-lovers story with phenomenal banter, incredible tension, and a beautifully executed opposites-attract dynamic. Aiden and Rosie’s journey from rivals to lovers is both hilarious and heartwarming, making it one of my favorite reads of the year. I cannot recommend it enough!

review: This charming enemies-to-lovers rom-com unfolds in the literary world, featuring Rosie, a Peruvian-American aspiring writer who sacrifices everything to chase her dreams at NYU. Her arch-nemesis, Aiden, a pretentious literary fiction writer, intensifies their rivalry until their professor compels them to collaborate on a love story that parallels their own evolving relationship. The premise is both engaging and clever, enhanced by a delightful grumpy-sunshine dynamic.

In this story, Rosie embodies optimism and a deep passion for writing romance, even in the face of the genre's frequent dismissal. In contrast, Aiden's critical and dismissive attitude towards her work creates an engaging dynamic between them. Their interactions are humorous and endearing, ultimately heating up during moments like co-writing a sex scene over a phone call.

This book is a delightful blend of humor, heartfelt moments, and a touch of steam, making it a true crowd-pleaser. It resonates especially with long-time romance readers and writers who appreciate the genre's often underestimated value. The narrative skillfully balances wit, romance, and emotional depth.
conclusion: This is a well-crafted, engaging rom-com with a unique premise, strong character dynamics, and excellent audio narration. It’s funny, heartfelt, and steamy, making it a must-read for romance enthusiasts and writers alike.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**

Their rivalry escalates, and their professor forces them to collaborate on writing a love story together, which mirrors their own evolving relationship. The setup is engaging and clever, with a grumpy-sunshine dynamic that works well.

- **Characters:**  
  Rosie is optimistic and passionate about writing romance, despite the genre often being dismissed. Aiden is critical and dismissive of her work, creating a compelling contrast between the two. Their dynamic is funny, cute, and eventually becomes quite steamy, especially during moments like co-writing a sex scene over a phone call.

- **Writing Style and Tone:**  
  The book is humorous, heartfelt, and eventually steamy, making it a crowd-pleaser. It particularly resonates with long-time romance readers or writers who feel the genre is undervalued. The narrative effectively balances humor, romance, and emotional depth.

- **Audio Narration:**  
  The audio narration is excellent, featuring dual narrators who capture the essence of the characters. They also read excerpts from the book being written within the story, adding an extra layer of immersion.

- **Appeal to Readers:**  
  This book is likely to appeal to fans of romance, especially those who enjoy enemies-to-lovers tropes and meta-narratives about writing. It also speaks to writers who feel the romance genre deserves more respect.

**Conclusion:**  
This is a well-crafted, engaging rom-com with a unique premise, strong character dynamics, and excellent audio narration. It’s funny, heartfelt, and steamy, making it a must-read for romance enthusiasts and writers alike.

**Rating Scores:**  
4.5 stars rounded up.

review: Aiden and Rosie’s journey of expressing their feelings and growing closer through their shared passion for writing was a highlight of the story. The parallel between their real-life romance and that of their fictional characters added a compelling creative layer to the narrative.

Their contrasting personalities enhance their witty banter, making their interactions both enjoyable and engaging. Although Aiden initially comes across as frustrating, he becomes more endearing as he gradually opens up to Rosie. The intertwining of their relationship with the romance of their book characters, Hunter and Max, offers a unique and delightful narrative twist.
conclusion: This debut novel was a fantastic read, blending humor, romance, and creative storytelling. The chemistry between the main characters, their growth, and the clever narrative structure made it a memorable experience. I highly recommend it to fans of rivals-to-lovers tropes and heartfelt romances.

review: This story centers on a mentor's suggestion for two individuals to collaborate as co-authors on a manuscript. Their writing journey is both unique and romantic, filled with entertaining banter. The simplicity of the narrative creates a lighthearted atmosphere, evoking joy and a delightful sense of "kilig."

In this captivating story, aspiring authors Rosie Maxwell and Aiden Huntington clash due to their contrasting personalities and writing styles. Rosie thrives on happy-ever-after tales, embodying a hopeless romantic, while Aiden embraces literary fiction, preferring to expose life's tragic realities. Their dynamic is heightened by playful critiques in class, revealing both tension and undeniable chemistry. This engaging enemies-to-lovers journey is heartwarming, showcasing the evolution of their relationship and collaborative writing.
conclusion: This book delivers a delightful and heartwarming romance, blending the charm of *Beach Read* and *The Hating Game*. With its engaging characters, unique premise, and undeniable chemistry, it’s a story that will leave you with butterflies and a smile.

review: The pacing of this story is a slow burn, a style I don't usually favor, yet it works remarkably well here. The gradual buildup of sexual tension kept me engaged throughout. Surprisingly, the typical third-act breakup, which I often find frustrating, was executed so effectively that it felt satisfying instead. The narrative follows Rosie and Aiden, who start off as adversaries but are compelled to work together on a writing project. Their transformation from enemies to lovers is rich in tension and romance. The alternating settings of New York and Tennessee further enhance the story's depth.
Rosie and Aiden's relationship develops organically, as their playful bickering transforms into genuine affection. Their chemistry is undeniable, and their growth feels authentic.
The writing is engaging and immersive, striking a perfect balance of humor, tension, and emotional depth. The book offers delightful cheesiness, creating a cozy yet captivating tone.
The book weaves together several themes and tropes, including a charming classroom romance, a captivating plot within a plot, and delightful holiday ambiance.

This book profoundly changed my perception of tropes I typically dislike. I found myself wishing for a 600-page extended edition, as I thoroughly enjoyed the experience and felt genuinely sad when it came to an end.
conclusion: This book is a delightful blend of enemies-to-lovers romance, slow-burn tension, and cozy vibes. It masterfully executes tropes I typically dislike, leaving me thoroughly impressed and emotionally invested. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a captivating and heartwarming read.

review: The story revolves around two aspiring writers, Rosie and Aiden, who come from starkly different backgrounds. Their rivalry ignites from their first encounter in class, culminating in a workshop ultimatum: to save their semester, they must co-write a novel. As they collaborate, the novel becomes a medium for sharing their perspectives, allowing them to gradually understand and connect with each other.
The plot and characters are exceptional. Rosie and Aiden are well-developed, with a compelling dynamic. Even the side characters are entertaining and endearing.
The writing is engaging, and the character development is exceptional.

review: This is one of the most heartbreakingly beautiful romance stories I’ve ever encountered. It follows the journey of rivals Rosie and Aiden, who are compelled to collaborate on a tragic love story. Their initial animosity evolves into a profound love that feels both timeless and fated. The emotional intensity is raw and palpable, like a frayed nerve laid bare to the elements, reminiscent of the tension found in dramione or reylo fanfics (IYKYK).

Rosie and Aiden’s personal stories are well-developed and thought-provoking, providing a strong foundation for their actions and reactions. Aiden’s crude language contrasts with his endearing label for Rosie as his best friend, adding depth to their relationship. Additionally, Rosie’s midsized representation is a refreshing and important aspect of the narrative.
The epistolary elements enrich the romance, and the writing is exceptional. This is not only my favorite book of 2024 but may well remain my favorite for life.
Set against the vibrant backdrop of New York City, the story exudes charm. The depiction of a Peruvian family Christmas brings warmth and depth, enhancing the narrative's emotional resonance.
The themes of longing for home and family while chasing ambitious dreams are both relatable and deeply poignant.
The yearning and emotional turmoil are so profound they may leave you feeling nauseous.

This love story is intensely captivating, blending beauty and tenderness with a profound emotional depth. The witty banter, underlying tension, and enemies-to-lovers dynamic are expertly crafted. The incorporation of the one-bed trope and a shared Google Doc stands out as one of the best I've encountered. The spice level is a solid 3/5.
conclusion: This novel is a masterpiece of romance, blending raw emotion, brilliant character development, and unique storytelling techniques. It’s a love story that feels destined, with moments so tender and intense they leave a lasting impact. It’s my favorite book of 2024 and possibly for the rest of my life.

review: This story excels with its flawless plot, centering on academic rivals Rosie and Aiden, who must collaborate on a romance novel for class. The clever “book within a book” concept is masterfully executed, as they exchange love letters throughout their narrative. As the characters in their story develop romantic feelings, Rosie and Aiden find themselves experiencing the same emotions in real life, adding depth and intrigue to the narrative.

Rosie is both relatable and inspiring, particularly for romance enthusiasts and those from Tennessee. Her passion for her art is truly captivating. Aiden, affectionately dubbed Clark Kent, has quickly become one of my favorite male main characters. His deep devotion to Rosie and his endearing obsession with her add depth to the story. The tension, bickering, and banter between Rosie and Aiden are exceptional, making their dynamic a joy to read.

The author's writing is remarkable for a debut novel, with well-crafted scenes that resonate emotionally. Memorable moments, such as the Christmas scenes and Aiden buying books for Rosie, are especially heartwarming.
The setting is vividly described, making me want to rush to New York immediately. The city feels alive and essential to the story.

This story evoked powerful emotions, leaving me teary-eyed by the end. The quote, “I had the time of my life making you mad, but loving you has been so much better,” beautifully captures the novel's emotional depth.
conclusion: *Not in My Book* is a dream come true for romance readers. With its perfect plot, relatable and lovable characters, exceptional writing, vivid setting, and emotional depth, this debut novel by the author is an absolute gem. It’s a story that stays with you long after you’ve finished reading.

review: Rosie is a feisty and lovable character, passionately devoted to writing romance, while Aiden embodies the ideal book boyfriend—grumpy, overprotective, slightly nerdy, and delightfully vulgar. Their chemistry and witty banter create an engaging dynamic, making their verbal sparring a highlight of the story.

This book offers a delightful mix of familiar tropes, including enemies-to-friends-to-lovers, fighting as flirting, forced proximity, slow burn, opposites attract, and grumpy-sunshine dynamics. It's a perfect choice for readers who appreciate a sassy Peruvian heroine, academic settings, and plenty of romantic tension.

This story beautifully combines elements reminiscent of Ali Hazelwood and Emily Henry, featuring academic rivals, forced proximity, and a slow-burn romance. I especially enjoyed the story-within-a-story aspect and would love to read the romance novel that Rosie and Aiden co-wrote.
This book had me kicking my feet, giggling, swooning, and blushing. It was a thoroughly engaging and emotionally rewarding read.
conclusion: This book was an absolute delight! I loved everything about it—the characters, the writing, the tension, and the narration. It’s a must-read for fans of romantic comedies with academic settings and slow-burn relationships.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Engagement and Emotional Impact:**  
  The book had me kicking my feet, giggling, swooning, and blushing. It was an incredibly engaging and emotionally satisfying read.  

- **Writing Style and Themes:**  
  The story felt like a mix of Ali Hazelwood and Emily Henry, blending academic rivals, forced proximity, and a slow-burn romance. The "story within a story" aspect was particularly enjoyable, and I would love to read the romance book that Rosie and Aiden co-wrote.  

- **Characters:**  
  Rosie is feisty, lovable, and passionate about writing romance. Aiden is the perfect book boyfriend—grumpy, overprotective, damaged, a little nerdy, and with a filthy mouth. Their chemistry, banter, and verbal sparring were top-tier.  

- **Narration (Audiobook):**  
  Frankie Corzo’s narration was exceptional. Her Southern accent and Spanish pronunciations brought Rosie to life, making the audiobook a pleasure to listen to.  

- **Tropes and Appeal:**  
  The book includes tropes like enemies-to-friends-to-lovers, fighting as flirting, forced proximity, slow burn, opposites attract, and grumpy x sunshine dynamics. It’s perfect for readers who enjoy a sassy Peruvian heroine, academic settings, and romantic tension.  

**Conclusion:**  
This book was an absolute delight! I loved everything about it—the characters, the writing, the tension, and the narration. It’s a must-read for fans of romantic comedies with academic settings and slow-burn relationships.  

**Rating Scores:**  
- Overall Rating: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️  
- Spice Level: 🌶️🌶️🌶️  

**Acknowledgments:**  
Thank you to Alcove Press, RB Media, Katie Holt, and NetGalley for the ARC. I received an advanced copy for free and am leaving this review voluntarily.  

**Connect With Me:**  
[Instagram](https://instagram.com/shanisshelves?i...) | [TikTok](https://www.tiktok.com/@shanisshelves)

review: I absolutely loved the premise of two academic rivals in graduate school who are compelled to co-author a book due to their fiery clashes in class. The way they channel their true feelings for each other through the characters in their story is both engaging and enjoyable to read.

The interplay between the female lead, a romance writer, and the male lead, a literary fiction author skeptical of happy endings, was captivating. Their collaboration on a romantic book meant to defy conventional endings introduced an engaging tension. The slow-burn romance unfolded at just the right pace, with the added angst providing significant emotional depth. A standout moment was their spicy scene, crafted before any romance blossomed, which was particularly memorable and skillfully executed.

One of my favorite aspects of the story was the chapters featuring the characters writing scenes together. The seamless transition from playful banter and arguments to unspoken romantic tension was beautifully executed. Despite the narrative being told from a single point of view, the excerpts from their writing offered valuable insights into the male lead's emotions, enriching the overall depth of the story.

The novel skillfully blends several of my favorite tropes, such as academic rivals to lovers, a book-about-books theme, and the classic "only one bed" scenario. These elements are seamlessly integrated into the narrative.
conclusion: This was an incredibly enjoyable read with a unique premise, well-developed characters, and a satisfying slow-burn romance. The blend of academic rivalry, creative collaboration, and emotional tension made for a compelling story. I’ll definitely be reading more from this author!
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Plot Concept:**  
  I absolutely loved the premise of two academic rivals in graduate school being forced to write a book together due to their inability to control their temperaments in class. The idea of them using the characters in their book to indirectly express their true feelings for each other was incredibly engaging and fun to read.  

- **Character Dynamics:**  
  The dynamic between the female lead, a romance writer, and the male lead, a literary fiction writer who doesn’t believe in happily ever afters, was fascinating. Their collaboration on a romantic book that wasn’t supposed to end happily created a lot of tension and intrigue.  

- **Writing Style and Structure:**  
  The chapters where they were writing scenes together were some of my favorite moments. The transition from banter and arguments to romantic undertones they were too scared to admit aloud was executed beautifully. Even though the story is told from a single POV, the excerpts from the book they’re writing provided glimpses into the male lead’s feelings, which added depth to the narrative.  

- **Romantic Development:**  
  The slow-burn romance was perfectly paced, and the angst added emotional weight to the story. The spicy scene they wrote together before anything happened between them was particularly memorable and well-done.  

- **Tropes and Themes:**  
  The novel incorporated several tropes I adore, including academic rivals to lovers, a book-about-books theme, and the classic “only one bed” scenario. These elements were woven seamlessly into the story.  

**Conclusion:**  
This was an incredibly enjoyable read with a unique premise, well-developed characters, and a satisfying slow-burn romance. The blend of academic rivalry, creative collaboration, and emotional tension made for a compelling story. I’ll definitely be reading more from this author!  

**Rating Scores:**  
- Overall: 5/5 stars ⭐️  
- Spice Level: 2/5 stars 🌶️

review: I've never encountered a story quite this meta, where characters co-write a novel featuring fictional versions of themselves. They express thoughts and emotions that Rosie and Aiden aren’t yet brave enough to share with each other.
The writing was exceptional, reflecting the author's meticulous attention to every sentence.
I was captivated by the nuanced conversations between Rosie and Aiden about storytelling, writing, and their distinct genres of romance and literary fiction.
The humor was perfectly timed, and throughout the book, a slow-building, delicious tension kept readers engaged—definitely worth the wait!
conclusion: This book is a masterful blend of phenomenal writing, layered dialogue, perfectly timed humor, and a slow-building tension that pays off beautifully. The meta-narrative structure adds a unique and captivating layer, while the romantic and intimate moments are both spicy and tender. A new favorite author has emerged, and this book is one I’ll be eagerly recommending.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Writing Quality:**  
  The writing was absolutely phenomenal; it felt like the author labored over every single sentence.  

- **Dialogue and Themes:**  
  I was struck by the layered conversations that Rosie and Aiden had about storytelling, writing, and their respective genres (romance and literary fiction).  

- **Humor and Pacing:**  
  The humor came at JUST the right moments, and threaded throughout the entire book was this slow-building, delicious tension that was WORTH. THE. WAIT!  

- **Narrative Structure and Meta-Elements:**  
  I've also NEVER read anything quite this meta, where the characters are cowriting a novel with fictional versions of themselves on the page, doing and saying things that Rosie and Aiden aren't brave enough to say to each other yet.  

- **Romantic and Intimate Moments:**  
  The spicy scenes were GIVING, and the romantic moments were so tender.  

- **Author Impression:**  
  Katie Holt is a new favorite author of mine, and I can't wait to scream about this book when it releases!  

**Conclusion:**  
This book is a masterful blend of phenomenal writing, layered dialogue, perfectly timed humor, and a slow-building tension that pays off beautifully. The meta-narrative structure adds a unique and captivating layer, while the romantic and intimate moments are both spicy and tender. Katie Holt has earned a spot as a new favorite author, and this book is one I’ll be eagerly recommending.  

**Rating Scores:**

review: The central conflict of the story revolves around whether Rosie and Aiden can overcome their personal challenges or if they are fated to remain alone. Their journey through friendship and love is both heartwarming and heartbreaking, making their eventual resolution all the more rewarding. The narrative follows Rosie, a romance writer, and Aiden, a literary fiction writer, who initially meet as rivals in a writing class at NYU. However, their dynamic shifts when they are compelled to collaborate on a project, leading to a deeper understanding of one another.

In this story, Rosie and Aiden's relationship transforms from adversaries to friends and ultimately to lovers, highlighting their emotional growth. The characters are engaging, as their playful bickering conceals deeper feelings of affection.
The narrative is engaging and well-paced, capturing my attention from beginning to end. The alternating perspectives and clever dialogue infuse the story with depth and charm.
This book seamlessly blends the charm of romance with the depth of literary fiction, set against the vibrant backdrop of New York City. It's a delightful fusion reminiscent of "Beach Read."
This story is rich with emotions like heartbreak and betrayal, keeping me deeply engaged. I laughed and cried, demonstrating its powerful ability to evoke strong feelings.
conclusion: This book is a captivating blend of romance and literary fiction, set against the vibrant backdrop of New York City. Rosie and Aiden's journey from enemies to lovers is filled with emotion, humor, and heartbreak, making it a truly unforgettable read. I was completely invested in their story and couldn't put the book down.

review: The incorporation of a book within a book enhances the story, adding an extra layer of enjoyment and creativity.

Rosie and Aiden share remarkable chemistry as they navigate their feelings through the characters in the book they are compelled to co-write. Their tension builds beautifully, making the slow burn all the more satisfying, and when they finally come together, it feels like a long-awaited payoff. Rosie, an optimistic romance writer, and Aiden, a cynical skeptic of love, complement each other perfectly in both their writing styles and personalities.
The notion of writing as a love language is elegantly portrayed in this story, as Rosie and Aiden convey their emotions through their co-written book when words fail them in person.

This novel skillfully utilizes popular tropes, including rivals-to-lovers, one bed, slow burn, opposites attract, and grumpy/sunshine dynamics. Its plot evokes the charm of *Beach Read* by Emily Henry, one of my all-time favorites.
conclusion: This novel is a delightful and engaging read, combining well-executed tropes, strong character chemistry, and a unique storytelling approach. The slow-burn romance between Rosie and Aiden is both satisfying and emotionally resonant, making it a standout in the genre.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Tropes and Themes:**  
  - The novel employs popular tropes such as rivals-to-lovers, one bed, slow burn, opposites attract, and grumpy/sunshine dynamics.  
  - The plot is reminiscent of *Beach Read* by Emily Henry, which is one of my favorite books.  

- **Character Dynamics and Chemistry:**  
  - Rosie and Aiden have incredible chemistry, especially as they channel their feelings into the characters of the book they are forced to co-write.  
  - Their tension builds up beautifully, making the slow burn satisfying, and when they finally get together, it feels like a long-awaited payoff.  
  - Rosie, a hopeful romance writer, and Aiden, a cynical non-believer in love, balance each other well both in their writing styles and personalities.  

- **Writing and Storytelling:**  
  - The concept of writing as a love language is beautifully executed, as Rosie and Aiden express their feelings through their co-written book when they can't say them aloud.  
  - The inclusion of a "book within a book" adds an extra layer of enjoyment and creativity to the story.  

- **Overall Enjoyment:**  
  - The novel was a lot of fun to read, with a compelling mix of tension, humor, and heartfelt moments.  

**Conclusion:**  
This novel is a delightful and engaging read, combining well-executed tropes, strong character chemistry, and a unique storytelling approach. The slow-burn romance between Rosie and Aiden is both satisfying and emotionally resonant, making it a standout in the genre.  

**Rating Scores:**  
4.5 rounded up to a 5!

review: I'm completely captivated by Rosie and Aiden. Their dynamic kept me on the edge of my seat—quick-witted and sharp-tongued, their relationship gradually blossoms from harsh jabs to tender moments. The slow burn between them was almost unbearable; I found myself pleading for them to finally kiss. After their constant bickering lands them in trouble with their professor, they are forced to co-write a novel for class. This situation compels them to spend more time together and reveal deeper aspects of themselves through their writing. Although the story is narrated from Rosie’s point of view, Aiden’s writing offers insight into his emotions, making me root for him even more and eager to read more of his work.

This book beautifully incorporates several tropes that I adored:  
- Enemies to Lovers  
- He Falls First  
- Grumpy x Sunshine  
- Forced Proximity  
- Slow Burn  
- Small-Town FMC  
- Big City MMC

Both Aiden and Rosie's yearning truly moved me—sickeningly so, in the best way possible. It’s been a while since a book made me feel this way, reminiscent of my experience with *Funny Story* and *Yours Truly* earlier this year. The characters are incredibly lovable, and their journey is both refreshing and deeply engaging.
conclusion: This novel is a captivating slow-burn romance with lovable characters, witty banter, and emotional depth. The enemies-to-lovers dynamic between Rosie and Aiden, combined with the forced proximity and pining, made for an unforgettable read. It’s a story I’ll revisit and highly recommend to anyone who enjoys heartfelt, character-driven romances.

  - The slow burn between them was excruciating—I was in PAIN, begging these two to just kiss already.  
  - Aiden and Rosie are forced to co-write a novel for their class after their bickering reaches a tipping point for their professor. This forces them to spend more time together and divulge a lot about themselves through their writing.

- **Emotional Engagement and Relatability:**

review: The story follows academic rivals Rosie and Aidan, who are forced to collaborate on a romance novel despite their competitive relationship.

Rosie, a bright and optimistic romance writer from Tennessee with half-Peruvian heritage, brings her charming Southern accent to New York City in pursuit of her dreams. In contrast, Aidan is a grumpy, anti-romance literary fiction writer from a wealthy yet dysfunctional family. His authentic New Yorker persona and disdain for tourist spots add depth to his character.
The writing is engaging, seamlessly blending humor, emotion, and tension. The slow-burn romance and academic rivalry are skillfully crafted, making the story truly compelling.

Set in New York City, particularly around NYU, this story resonates with readers familiar with the area, evoking a sense of nostalgia. The use of real NYC locations boosts the authenticity of the setting. Rosie’s proud half-Peruvian heritage enriches her character, while Aidan's complex family background and anti-romance stance offer a nuanced glimpse into his personality. Additionally, the song “Miss Americana & the Heartbreak Prince” serves as the perfect soundtrack, encapsulating the book's emotional tone.

The story seamlessly blurs the lines between its fictional characters, Max and Hunter, and their real-life emotions. It masterfully delves into themes of academic rivalry, forced proximity, slow-burn romance, and self-discovery through the art of writing.

The romance unfolds as a slow burn, featuring beloved tropes such as grumpy x sunshine, forced proximity, one bed, and he falls first. The chemistry between Rosie and Aidan is undeniable, making their transition from rivals to lovers truly satisfying.
conclusion: *Not In My Book* by the author is a delightful academic rivals-to-lovers romance with a perfect blend of humor, emotion, and NYC charm. The well-developed characters, authentic setting, and slow-burn romance make it a standout read, especially for fans of *The Hating Game* and *Book Lovers*.

review: In a final attempt to restore peace after a harsh critique session, the professor offers the students a choice: they can either leave the class or collaborate to write a novel.

Rosie and Aiden are poised to become the ultimate It couple in the realm of romance. As fellow writers in the same MFA program, their dynamic is filled with fiery exchanges; Aiden frequently critiques Rosie’s romance stories, while she counters with jabs at his literary fiction. Their journey from adversaries to lovers unfolds with remarkable authenticity.
The banter is exceptional—smart and hilariously sharp.
I will never fully recover, either physically or spiritually, from collaborating with them on a spicy scene in their shared Google Doc.

It's been ages since a romance made me giggle and kick my feet, but this one did just that. I found myself wholeheartedly rooting for the characters, and each development in their relationship made my heart flutter. I absolutely loved it and devoured the book in a day, unable to stay away from their captivating chemistry.
conclusion: This novel is a delightful and engaging romance that masterfully balances sharp banter, realistic character development, and emotional depth. It’s a must-read for anyone who enjoys witty dialogue, heartfelt moments, and a story that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

review: The plot was engaging, and I enjoyed the drama, despite some frustrating moments. My favorite scenes were when Rosie and Aiden collaborated on their book; those truly stood out. However, the ending felt incomplete, leaving me wishing for a more satisfying conclusion. The moment when Rosie touches the locket Aiden gave her, filled with pictures of their Christmas Eve and family memories, was sweet but left me wanting more. I found myself wishing I could have penned the epilogue myself!

Rosie, the female main character, is one of the most stubborn and immature characters I’ve encountered. Her doubtful mindset often drove me to frustration. However, her interactions with friends and family brought a level of depth to her character that was enjoyable to read.

The word "writhe" appears twice, and it's my least favorite term, which was quite off-putting. On the other hand, the repeated reference to Aiden's peacoat became an amusing running joke that stuck with me, even if it later triggered me when I came across the word in another book.
Despite its frustrations, this book stirred such deep emotions in me that I had to give it 5 stars. It's a rarity for a book to evoke such powerful feelings.
conclusion: This book was a rollercoaster of emotions, with a mix of frustrating character traits, engaging drama, and memorable moments. While the ending left something to be desired, the emotional impact and overall plot made it a worthwhile read.

review: A slow yet satisfying journey that feels purposeful throughout.

I loved their unique form of communication through writing, and getting both of their perspectives added depth to the story. Aiden quickly became a favorite book boyfriend; his gesture of buying romance novels to understand Rosie's tastes showcased his effort to be more romantic. Rosie is wonderfully imperfect, and their relationship feels authentic. Even when together, they continue to exchange playful insults and openly acknowledge their disagreements, choosing to work through challenges as a team.
The author truly excelled with this piece. I will certainly be recommending it for years to come, and it serves as an excellent introduction to the author's body of work.

If you enjoy stories featuring rivals-to-friends-to-lovers, grumpy x sunshine dynamics, forced proximity, and a touch of fake dating, all wrapped in a slow-burn romance, then this is the perfect read for you.

review: The story's premise of two academic rivals compelled to co-author a book blends romance and literary fiction in a unique and engaging way. The professor's ultimatum introduces high stakes, while the fine line between love and hate adds compelling tension. Their journey, particularly during their collaborative writing sessions, is both thrilling and heartwarming.

Rosie (Rosalinda) and Aiden are exceptionally well-developed characters. Their sharp and entertaining banter is intricately layered with underlying emotions. The gradual dismantling of their defenses as they bond over writing is beautifully depicted. The dual perspective—Rosie’s viewpoint paired with Aiden’s insights through the epigraphs—enhances the depth of their relationship, making their connection even more compelling.

This story is a delightful blend of fun, engagement, and immersion. The witty banter and tender emotional moments create a heartfelt experience. The meta layer introduced by the characters' writing adds depth to the narrative. Set against the cozy, romantic backdrop of winter holidays in New York, the atmosphere is truly enchanting.

This story is a delightful blend of steamy and sweet moments that had me gasping and kicking my legs in excitement. The pining and tension between Rosie and Aiden evoke the charm of *Pride and Prejudice*, making their eventual connection all the more satisfying.

The idea of rivals teaming up to write a book while grappling with their emotions is both fresh and inventive. The incorporation of epigraphs to present Aiden’s perspective serves as a clever narrative device, enhancing the story's depth.

review: This book offers a gratifying happily-ever-after (HEA), which I truly appreciate. It weaves together several beloved tropes: enemies-to-lovers, forced proximity, opposites attract, slow burn, and academic rivalry. The story follows NYU Creative Writing Program students Rosie and Aiden, who must collaborate on a novel to remain in the MFA program. Their evolution from rivals to lovers is captivating and engaging.

In this story, Rosie embodies the essence of a hopeless romantic—fun, vibrant, and occasionally immature—while Aiden presents a stark contrast as serious, arrogant, and disdainful of romance. Their constant bickering and undeniable tension create a dynamic and engaging relationship. Although their arguments can feel juvenile at times, the chemistry between them is unmistakable.

The author's writing is exceptional, filled with quotes that struck a deep chord with me. As a self-proclaimed romance snob, I was genuinely impressed by how the author's words captivated my attention.

This book was an emotional rollercoaster—I laughed, felt my heart weigh heavy, got annoyed during the bickering and three-act breakup, and even felt antsy during the spicy scenes. Experiencing such a wide range of emotions was truly a joy.
conclusion: I did not expect to enjoy this book as much as I did. The beautifully written story, engaging character dynamics, and emotional depth made it a memorable read. Despite my initial hesitation about the narration style, the book won me over with its charm and heartfelt moments. It was a pleasure to read and review this exceptional novel.

review: This novel is utterly charming, swoon-worthy, and a delight to read. It follows Rosie, who relocates to New York to pursue a graduate writing program with aspirations of penning romance novels, and her academic rival, Aiden, a literary fiction writer. Their playful banter becomes so disruptive that their professor compels them to collaborate on a class assignment, which mirrors their own budding romance. The seamless connection between their fictional narrative and real-life emotions is both skillfully crafted and emotionally resonant.

Rosie is a hopeful and optimistic character fiercely dedicated to defending her dreams and the romance genre she cherishes. Her deep connection to her Peruvian heritage is thoughtfully integrated into the plot. Aiden, a reclusive yet talented writer, secretly longs for Rosie and relishes their playful banter, which brings them closer together as they collaborate.

This novel passionately champions the romance book community, highlighting the genre's significance. Rosie’s strong connection to her Peruvian heritage infuses the story with depth and cultural richness.
conclusion: *Not in My Book* is a delightful and heartwarming read that combines a swoon-worthy love story with a celebration of the romance genre. The characters are well-developed, the cultural representation is meaningful, and the audiobook narration enhances the experience.

review: I appreciated how we got to know Aiden through his writing. While I usually prefer dual or multiple points of view, I found that a single perspective was more effective for this story. Although Aiden could be frustrating at times, I still enjoyed experiencing his emotions through his words.

The witty banter between Aiden and Rosie was exactly what I hoped for. *Not In My Book* perfectly captures my preferred take on the enemies-to-lovers trope: a modern setting where rivalry stems from intense emotions rather than blood feuds.

What an impressive debut! This charming, humorous, and steamy romance novel truly captivated me. "Not In My Book" is a delightful read—slightly spicy and a touch predictable. While the 'twists' were easy to foresee, this did not diminish my enjoyment. There's comfort in familiar storytelling, after all.
The story adds some heat towards the end. While it's not the spiciest moment, it certainly delivers a steamy intensity.
conclusion: This debut novel by the author is a delightful, funny, and steamy romance that balances predictability with charm. The witty banter between Aiden and Rosie, combined with the unique narrative style of getting to know Aiden through his writing, makes for an engaging read. While the plot twists are foreseeable, the familiarity adds to the comfort of the story. Fans of contemporary romance authors like Emily Henry, Ali Hazelwood, and Elena Armas will likely find this book enjoyable.

- **Character Dynamics:**  
  - "The witty banter between Aiden and Rosie was everything I wanted."  
  - "Not In My Book was my flavour of enemies to lovers - modern setting, no blood-sworn enemies, but more of a 'we are rivals and we are enemies because we handle our big feelings' kind of situation."  

- **Narrative Style and Perspective:**  
  - "I loved how we got to know Aiden through their writing. I tend to prefer dual or multi POV, but here it wouldn't be as effective or work for the story."  
  - "Although Aiden was frustrating at times (to say the least), I still enjoyed getting his emotions through his writing."  

- **Romantic Elements:**  
  - "There's some spice towards the end, and although it's not the spiciest of spice, it's definitely steamy and hot."  

- **Comparisons and Recommendations:**  
  - "I think lovers of Emily Henry, Ali Hazelwood, and Elena Armas would really enjoy this book!"  

**Conclusion:**  
This debut novel by Katie Holt is a delightful, funny, and steamy romance that balances predictability with charm. The witty banter between Aiden and Rosie, combined with the unique narrative style of getting to know Aiden through his writing, makes for an engaging read. While the plot twists are foreseeable, the familiarity adds to the comfort of the story. Fans of contemporary romance authors like Emily Henry, Ali Hazelwood, and Elena Armas will likely find this book enjoyable.  

**Rating Scores:**  
4.25⭐️ rounded up.

review: The story unfolds as a slow burn, featuring a level 2 spice—it's infrequent and takes time to build, but it's definitely present. After the third time the male main character clenched his jaw, I found myself flipping to the next chapter, pondering how much richer the narrative would have been with a dual POV. Eventually, you do gain some insight into the characters. However, the conflict in the end felt somewhat contrived; the characters are in their mid-twenties yet they break up over issues reminiscent of high school drama. Still, the story delivers a satisfying HEA (happily ever after).
The writing style is exceptional, drawing you in from the very first line. As a first-time reader of this author, I was genuinely impressed and found it impossible to put the book down.
The banter is incredibly entertaining.
conclusion: Overall, this was a captivating read with phenomenal writing and hilarious banter. While the pacing was slow and the conflict at the end felt a bit forced, the story delivers a satisfying HEA. The author’s skill left a strong impression, making this a memorable experience.

review: The idea of two characters collaborating on a book for their writing class and falling in love through the process is both charming and deeply satisfying. One standout moment is the scene they create together before officially becoming a couple, which feels fresh and playful.
The enemies-to-lovers trope gets a refreshing twist with Rosie and Aiden, offering a delightful new take on a classic theme.
One of the best romcoms I've read in ages! It captures the charm of a Hallmark movie that you never want to end.
conclusion: This novel is a delightful romcom that breathes new life into the enemies-to-lovers trope. With a unique and satisfying plot, excellent audiobook narration, and just the right amount of spice, it’s a story that feels both fresh and heartwarming.

- **Plot and Concept:**  
  - The concept of being required to write a book together for their writing class assignment and falling in love through the pages is irresistibly precious and immensely satisfying.  
  - The hottest scene, in my opinion, was the one they wrote together for the book before they ever got together, which felt fun and original.

review: The unique premise of the main characters co-writing a book together was both refreshing and engaging. Their journey unfolded in tandem with the story they were crafting, adding depth to the narrative.
The characters are richly developed and feel remarkably authentic. Their emotions are depicted so vividly that I experienced their joy, pain, and love as if they were my own.
The author has an exceptional command of language, rendering the characters' emotions deeply visceral and making the story unforgettable.
The book vividly portrays the chaos and magic of New York City, making the city feel alive and essential to the narrative.

This story skillfully weaves together beloved tropes such as rivals-to-lovers, slow burn, grumpy x sunshine, forced proximity, and the classic "only one bed" scenario. The Peruvian heroine and the male lead's steadfast devotion to the woman he loves add unique and heartwarming depth to the narrative.

This book evoked a profound emotional response in me, from butterflies in my stomach to a tingling sensation in my fingers. I even found myself crying during a passionate scene—not out of sadness, but because it was incredibly moving.
The banter was exceptional—witty, sharp, and brimming with chemistry. It had me laughing out loud, kicking my feet in delight, and gasping in surprise.
conclusion: *Not in My Book* by the author is a phenomenal debut that left an indelible mark on me. This book is easily one of my top reads of the year, if not all time.

review: This novel presents a captivating rivals-to-lovers narrative, enriched by a genuine rivalry and a slow-burn romance. Set against the backdrop of New York City, it follows two NYU students who must navigate their literary differences to collaborate on a work of fiction. The premise is engaging and skillfully executed, resulting in a layered love story that feels both fresh and heartfelt.

Rosie and Aiden shine as standout characters, boasting remarkable chemistry. Their witty dialogue and playful banter rank among the best I've read in romance novels, making me wish we could be best friends! Their romance is electric, especially during the writing scene at Aiden’s house, which truly took my breath away.

The writing is transportive, vividly capturing the essence of New York City through all its seasons. Having just returned from a holiday trip to the city, I found the experience even more special. The prose is immersive and evocative, bringing the setting to life.

This book beautifully weaves together beloved romance tropes like grumpy/sunshine, forced proximity, one bed, and slow burn. The inclusion of Latinx representation adds depth and authenticity to the narrative. The balance of yearning and angst culminates in an incredibly satisfying emotional payoff.
conclusion: This book is an absolute gem, delivering a perfect blend of romance, humor, and emotional depth. The characters, setting, and writing style come together to create a story that feels both intimate and expansive. I can’t wait to own a physical copy to annotate and revisit. Katie’s next release is already on my must-read list!
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Plot and Premise:**  
  The novel features an academic rivals-to-lovers story with a genuine rivalry and a slow-burn romance. Set in New York City, it follows two NYU students who must overcome their literary differences to collaborate on a work of fiction. The premise is engaging and well-executed, offering a layered love story that feels both fresh and heartfelt.  

- **Characters:**  
  Rosie and Aiden are standout characters with incredible chemistry. Their dialogue and banter are some of the best I’ve encountered in romance novels. I adored them so much that I wanted to be best friends with them! Their romance is electric, with moments that made my heart race, particularly the writing scene at Aiden’s house.  

- **Writing Style:**  
  The writing is transportive, vividly capturing the essence of New York City across all seasons. Reading this after my own trip to the city during the holidays made the experience even more special. The prose is immersive and evocative, making the setting feel alive.  

- **Themes and Tropes:**  
  The book includes beloved romance tropes such as grumpy/sunshine, forced proximity, one bed, and slow burn. It also features Latinx representation, which adds depth and authenticity to the story. The yearning and angst are perfectly balanced, making the emotional payoff incredibly satisfying.  

- **Comparisons and Recommendations:**  
  Fans of Emily Henry’s *Beach Read* will find this novel reminiscent of January and Gus’s college days. Comparable authors include Clare Gilmore and Caitlin Moss (*Goodbye Again*). This book is perfect for readers who enjoy banter, academic rivals, and a love story set against the backdrop of New York City.  

**Conclusion:**  
This book is an absolute gem, delivering a perfect blend of romance, humor, and emotional depth. The characters, setting, and writing style come together to create a story that feels both intimate and expansive. I can’t wait to own a physical copy to annotate and revisit. Katie’s next release is already on my must-read list!

review: The story follows rivals Rosie and Aiden, who must team up to write a romance novel after an incident in their NYU writing class. Rosie champions the classic Happily Ever After trope, while Aiden prefers literary fiction with realistic, often tragic endings. As they collaborate, they gain a deeper understanding of one another, prompting the question: will they write their own love story?

Rosie is a relatable and witty main character whose passion for Taylor Swift adds a modern and charming dimension to her personality. The contrasting storytelling perspective of Aiden creates a compelling dynamic between the two protagonists. Additionally, Rosie’s supportive friend group and family enrich the narrative, grounding the story and enhancing its relatability.

The winter setting in New York creates a cozy and immersive backdrop that enhances the novel's romantic and emotional tone. Delightful food references and insights into Peruvian culture add unique and engaging details, enriching the overall story.
The chemistry between Rosie and Aiden is electric, with a slow-burn romance that brims with angst and emotional tension, making it a satisfying read for genre enthusiasts.
conclusion: This book is a perfect blend of romance, humor, and cultural richness, with well-developed characters and a captivating slow-burn love story. It delivers everything one could want in a romance novel and more, making it a highly enjoyable and memorable read.

review: The author skillfully portrays the complexity of intense emotions. The female protagonist harbors a deep hatred for the male lead, yet she is simultaneously drawn to his attractiveness. This push-and-pull dynamic is what makes the enemies-to-lovers trope so captivating.

The author expertly weaves classic romance tropes into the narrative, ensuring they feel natural rather than contrived. The writing is both sharp and evocative; for instance, the line “The last thing I ever expected was for Aiden’s laugh to make me feel like the drive home after a long day” beautifully encapsulates the comfort of finding solace in another person.

The cover art is charming and captivating, making it a book I'd choose off the shelf even without a free copy. From the very beginning, the story drew me in with its tension and witty banter. The pacing was spot on, keeping me fully engaged from start to finish.

The premise of two MFA candidates, constantly bickering while forced to co-write a novel, is brilliant. Their contrasting styles—his literary fiction and her romance—create a delightful balance of conflict and humor. The enemies-to-lovers trope is executed flawlessly, blending attraction and animosity in just the right measure.
conclusion: This book is a must-read for fans of romance and enemies-to-lovers tropes. It’s engaging, well-written, and cleverly structured, with a perfect balance of humor, tension, and emotional depth. The book-within-a-book concept adds an extra layer of enjoyment, making it a standout read.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Engagement and Pacing:**  
  The book immediately drew me in with its tension and banter. The pacing was perfect, and I was fully invested from the start.  

- **Premise and Plot:**  
  The premise of two MFA candidates who can’t stop bickering and are forced to write a novel together is brilliant. The dynamic between the characters—he writes literary fiction, she writes romance—creates a perfect balance of conflict and humor. The enemies-to-lovers trope is executed flawlessly, with the right mix of attraction and animosity.  

- **Character Dynamics:**  
  The author, Holt, perfectly captures the complexity of strong emotions. The female protagonist hates the male lead but is also obsessed with him because he’s attractive. This push-and-pull dynamic is what makes enemies-to-lovers so compelling.  

- **Use of Literary Devices:**  
  The idea of the characters writing a book together as a way to resolve their mutual obsession is a clever and well-utilized literary device. It keeps the plot engaging and provides a natural reason for the characters to interact.  

- **Genre Commentary:**  
  The book defends the romance genre against criticism, which I appreciated. It highlights the profitability and value of romance, while also critiquing the dullness often found in literary fiction.  

- **Book-within-a-Book Concept:**  
  The inclusion of a book within the book was a standout feature. I became just as invested in that story as I did in the main plot. It served as a study of what makes a good romance novel, exploring character emotions and the concept of a Happily Ever After.  

- **Tropes and Writing Style:**  
  The author skillfully incorporates all the classic romance tropes without making them feel forced. The writing is sharp and evocative, with lines like, “The last thing I ever expected was for Aiden’s laugh to make me feel like the drive home after a long day,” perfectly capturing the comfort of finding solace in someone.  

- **Cover Art and Appeal:**  
  The cover art is adorable and eye-catching. It’s the kind of book I would pick up off a shelf even if I hadn’t received a free copy.  

**Conclusion:**  
This book is a must-read for fans of romance and enemies-to-lovers tropes. It’s engaging, well-written, and cleverly structured, with a perfect balance of humor, tension, and emotional depth. The book-within-a-book concept adds an extra layer of enjoyment, making it a standout read.

review: Rosie and Aiden's characters were exceptionally well-developed, with Aiden truly standing out (my goodness, that man!). The nemesis dynamic between them was brilliantly executed; their initial hatred and tension were palpable from the very first page. I loved how their banter evolved alongside their relationship. The interactions between the characters were a highlight, featuring 100/10 banter that had me kicking my feet, giggling, and completely losing my mind throughout the story.

The novel's premise facilitates a unique interaction between the main characters, particularly through the expertly executed book-within-a-book micro trope. The scenes of Rosie and Aiden co-writing stand out as some of the best romance moments I've encountered in a long time. The excerpts from their writing enrich the narrative, and I appreciated how key moments in their relationship emerged from this creative process, enhancing the authenticity and eloquence of their connection.

This novel skillfully embraces and subverts familiar tropes, particularly the enemies-to-lovers arc and slow-burn romance. Rosie and Aiden, both writers, provide delightful self-awareness that adds a layer of meta-commentary I truly appreciated. Additionally, the exploration of genre versus literary fiction through their perspectives is a brilliant touch.

The workshop setting was expertly crafted, and I felt a deep camaraderie with Rosie, particularly as a fellow genre fiction writer.
conclusion: This novel is a masterful blend of relatable characters, witty banter, and a unique premise that celebrates the art of writing and storytelling. review: Rosie was an exceptional protagonist to follow over the course of 350 pages. She is headstrong and confident, yet her relatable mistakes and snap judgments enhance her depth. I thoroughly enjoyed her journey of self-discovery, both in her writing and her evolving feelings for Aiden. The romance between Rosie and Aiden was electric, filled with chemistry, tension, and a thrilling dynamic that kept me craving every moment of their interactions. I would have happily played the awkward third wheel, soaking up every nuance of their relationship. The side characters added delightful flavor and fiery energy to the narrative, enriching the world around Rosie. I found myself invested in their romances as well and would love to see spin-offs delving into their individual stories.
The book is expertly crafted and remarkably meta, creating a fun and engaging reading experience.
conclusion: Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this book. The well-crafted writing, relatable characters, sizzling romance, and vibrant setting made it a memorable read. I would happily revisit Rosie and Aiden’s world and eagerly anticipate any future stories set in this universe.

  The book was well-written and extremely meta, which made for a fun and engaging reading experience.  

- **Main Character (Rosie):**  
  Rosie was a fantastic protagonist to follow for 350 pages. She was headstrong and confident, yet relatable due to her mistakes and snap judgments. I thoroughly enjoyed accompanying her on her journey of self-discovery, both in her writing and in her evolving feelings for Aiden.  

- **Romantic Lead (Aiden):**  
  Aiden was initially rude and grumpy, but his softness for Rosie made him endearing. Watching him turn into an "absolute simp" for her was adorable. His tall stature added to his charm, and I found myself wanting to hug his "hurt little heart" while rooting for him and Rosie to get together.  

- **Romantic Chemistry and Tension:**  
  The romance between Rosie and Aiden was electric. Their chemistry, the tension, the loathing, and the eventual *ahem* non-loathing had me craving every moment of their interactions. I wanted to be their awkward third wheel forever, soaking up every crumb of their relationship.  

- **Side Characters:**  
  The side characters were a delightful addition to the story. They brought extra flavor, support, and fiery energy, making the world feel richer. I found myself rooting for their romances as well and would love to see spin-offs exploring their individual stories.  

- **Setting (New York City):**  
  As a New Yorker, I couldn’t resist the book’s love letter to NYC. The setting added an extra layer of charm and authenticity to the story.  

**Conclusion:**  
Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this book. The well-crafted writing, relatable characters, sizzling romance, and vibrant setting made it a memorable read. I would happily revisit Rosie and Aiden’s world and eagerly anticipate any future stories set in this universe.

review: The story centers on graduate students Rosie and Aiden, academic rivals who are compelled to collaborate on a novel for class. As the characters collaborate on their book, their true feelings for each other emerge through their writing, revealing the intertwining of their story and their lives. The sharp insults they exchanged at the start were striking, but as their friendship blossomed, they shared many tender moments.

conclusion: *Not in My Book* is a captivating contemporary romance that masterfully blends humor, tension, and heartfelt moments. review: The novel follows Rosie and Aiden, two writing students in New York with contrasting literary tastes—she favors romance, while he prefers literary fiction. Their fierce rivalry takes an unexpected turn when their professor mandates a collaboration: they must co-write a novel that merges their genres or face expulsion. This premise skillfully weaves together elements of rivals-to-lovers, forced proximity, and slow-burn romance, resulting in a captivating and well-executed narrative.

Rosie and Aiden's relationship develops in a nuanced way, marked by both progress and setbacks. Their struggles with open communication often manifest through the characters they create in their joint novel, Max(ine) and Hunter. I enjoyed the interplay between their real-life relationship and the fictional one, as each enriched the other. While I found Rosie occasionally immature and wished for a deeper exploration of her Peruvian heritage, Aiden emerged as a standout character—initially cold and haughty but possessing hidden sensitivity. His gradual emotional depth reminded me of Mr. Darcy, which I loved.

This book evokes the charm of works by Mariana Zapata, Elena Armas, and Emily Henry’s *Beach Read*, as well as the nostalgic vibe of 90s New York rom-coms like *When Harry Met Sally*. These comparisons heightened my enjoyment, making the novel feel both fresh and familiar. It serves as a meta-exploration of writing itself, rich with references to romance tropes and literary discussions, while also addressing broader themes such as human relationships, self-confidence, and the fear of vulnerability. The author skillfully weaves these elements throughout the narrative, and I found myself highlighting numerous passages that resonated with me. The dual narrative structure, which intertwines the protagonists’ real lives with their fictional creations, was a brilliant and well-executed choice.
conclusion: This debut novel is a remarkable achievement, combining a clever premise, well-developed characters, and thoughtful exploration of writing and relationships. Despite minor flaws, such as Rosie’s occasional immaturity and underdeveloped cultural background, the story captivated me from start to finish. I eagerly anticipate owning a physical copy to revisit its highlights.

review: The story follows Rosalinda (Rosie) and Aidan as they navigate their forced collaboration on a final project. Their transformation from enemies to lovers unfolds gradually, marked by expertly crafted tension and satisfying payoff. The first-person perspective immerses us in Rosie's thoughts, while Aidan's writing offers a candid look into his emotions, deepening their connection and enhancing the romance.

This book provides a genuine representation of Peruvian culture, which I truly appreciated. The inclusion of alfajores, Inca Kola, and midnight Christmas traditions created a heartfelt depiction rarely seen in mainstream romance novels. While Rosie's backstory, particularly her relationship with her ex, is thoroughly explored, Aidan's past relationships feel underdeveloped. A deeper look at his romantic history would have added depth to his pessimism and enriched his character.

The writing is engaging, eliciting laughter, gasps, and tears. However, some conflicts between Rosie and Aidan come across as overly childish and exaggerated, relying too much on the "enemies to lovers" trope, which occasionally undermines the realism of their dynamic.

The book addresses the stigma surrounding the romance genre, particularly through Aidan's initial disdain for it, which Rosie perceives as a dismissal of her passions. I admired Rosie's steadfast defense of romance and her determination to pursue her goals despite criticism. This not only added depth to her character but also enriched the overall narrative.
conclusion: This debut novel by the author is a heartfelt and culturally rich romance that many readers, especially romance enthusiasts, will connect with. While the enemies-to-lovers dynamic and cultural representation are standout elements, the occasional childish conflicts and underdeveloped aspects of Aidan's backstory prevent it from being a perfect read. Still, it’s a highly enjoyable and promising debut.

- **Plot and Character Dynamics:**  
  The story revolves around Rosalinda (Rosie) and Aidan, who are forced to collaborate on a final project. Their journey from enemies to lovers is a slow burn with well-executed tension and payoff. The first-person POV allows us to see Rosie's perspective, but Aidan's writing provides a raw and honest glimpse into his feelings, making their connection feel deeply personal and romantic.  

- **Themes and Genre Commentary:**  
  The book tackles the stigma around romance as a genre, with Aidan initially looking down on it, which Rosie interprets as a dismissal of her passions. I admired Rosie's unwavering defense of romance and her refusal to compromise her goals, even when faced with criticism. This added depth to her character and the story.  

- **Character Development and Backstory:**  
  While Rosie's backstory, including her ex, is well-explored, I felt Aidan's past relationships were underdeveloped. A bit more insight into his history with love would have added depth to his pessimism and made his character more nuanced.  

- **Writing Style and Pacing:**  
  The writing is engaging, with moments that made me laugh, gasp, and cry. However, some of the conflicts between Rosie and Aidan felt overly childish and exaggerated, leaning too heavily into the "enemies but secretly obsessed" trope, which occasionally made their dynamic feel unrealistic.  

**Conclusion:**  
This debut novel by Katie Holt is a heartfelt and culturally rich romance that many readers, especially romance enthusiasts, will connect with. review: While the story was engaging, I felt there were some loose ends left unresolved. A bit more closure would have enhanced the experience, but I won't spoil anything by going into details.

I was truly fond of Rosie and admired her confidence in seeking criticism, a quality I wish I had as someone who fears workshopping my writing. Aaron's dry humor was a highlight for me; he was genuinely hilarious. I found myself wanting to roll my eyes affectionately at both him and Rosie, as their feelings for each other were so evident, even to me as a reader.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book! It was incredibly comforting, reminiscent of a blend between *The Hating Game* and *Beach Read*, with *The Spanish Love Deception* as its charming aunt. It was precisely what I needed.
This book, while reminiscent of others, truly stands on its own. No one "owns" a trope; it's the unique setting and characters that set it apart.
conclusion: Overall, this was an amazing debut novel! It was comforting, humorous, and relatable, with a strong focus on the value of the romance genre. While I had minor issues with the miscommunication trope and some loose ends, I thoroughly enjoyed the story and characters.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Comfort and Enjoyment:**  
  I really, really enjoyed this book! It felt so comforting. It reminded me of a mix between *The Hating Game* and *Beach Read*, with *The Spanish Love Deception* as its aunt. It was exactly what I needed.  

- **Originality and Trope Use:**  
  While I can see the ties between this book and others, I feel like this one stands on its own. No one “owns” a trope, and the setting and characters made it unique.  

- **Character Development (Rosie):**  
  I was so fond of Rosie and really looked up to her. As someone who fears workshopping my writing, I admired how she craved criticism because she knew she was a wonderful writer.  

- **Character Development (Aaron):**  
  Aaron was hilarious, especially with his dry humor, which I love. I wanted to fondly roll my eyes at him and Rosie because their feelings for each other were so obvious to everyone, including me as a reader.  

- **Romance Genre Appreciation:**  
  I adored the focus on romance as a genre and its worthiness. It bothers me how many MFA programs dismiss romance and fantasy, when they are wonderful genres. I loved how Rosie stuck to her guns and fought for herself and the genre. Katie’s descriptions of romance books were spot-on—they are more than just romance plots.  

- **Miscommunication Trope:**  
  I’m not a huge fan of miscommunication tropes, and I do think Rosie and Aaron overreacted. However, their reasoning made sense based on their past experiences.  

- **Pacing and Resolution:**  
  I felt like there were some loose threads at the end. I would have loved a bit more wrap-up, but I won’t spoil anything by mentioning specifics.  

- **Author Connection:**  
  Katie is a fellow bookstagrammer, which I love. I wish her all the success in her future!  

**Conclusion:**  
Overall, this was an amazing debut novel! It was comforting, humorous, and relatable, with a strong focus on the value of the romance genre. While I had minor issues with the miscommunication trope and some loose ends, I thoroughly enjoyed the story and characters.  

**Rating Scores:**  
4.5 stars rounded up.  

Thank you to the author and publisher for a free ARC in exchange for my honest review.

review: The sexual tension between Aiden and Rosie was palpable, making me root for their romance. The strong buildup and engaging pacing kept me hooked throughout. Her aspiration to become a successful romance writer, coupled with her supportive family, adds depth to her character. In contrast, Aiden grapples with his father's disappointment over his decision to pursue writing instead of joining the family’s financial tech company. The premise of their forced collaboration on a novel is both intriguing and well-executed.

The evolving relationship between Aiden and Rosie was a standout aspect of the book. Initially fierce enemies, they gradually come to admire one another, creating an authentic and engaging dynamic that I thoroughly enjoyed. The author's witty and engaging writing style brings the likable characters to life, making it a book I couldn't put down. I was eager to see how the story would unfold. This debut author shows great promise, and I'm excited to read more of her work in the future.

review: The story follows Rosie, a small-town writer from Tennessee, who relocates to New York City for grad school at NYU. Her nemesis, Aiden, is in her workshop course and frequently critiques her writing. When their professor forces them to collaborate on a love story without a happy ending or risk failing the class, the plot unfolds as a rom-com within a rom-com, skillfully blending the enemies-to-lovers trope with a creative narrative structure. Divided into seasons, the book exudes a cozy and romantic atmosphere. The inclusion of excerpts from Rosie and Aiden’s collaborative work adds a brilliant layer, heightening the anticipation of their evolving romance.

Rosie and Aiden are well-crafted, relatable characters whose witty banter kept me thoroughly engaged. Their interactions, especially during arguments, felt refreshingly realistic; neither character is perfect, and their defensiveness adds depth to their humanity. The transition from enemies to lovers unfolds naturally and compellingly.

The writing is engaging and humorous, maintaining a lighthearted tone that kept me giggling and smiling throughout. The witty dialogue between Rosie and Aiden truly stands out, making the book a delightful read.

Although the story is primarily grounded in reality, certain moments, such as the Christmas Eve scene, demand a bit of suspension of disbelief. Nevertheless, I enjoyed the book immensely, and these instances did not diminish my overall experience.

This book offers a cozy and romantic experience that left me feeling warm and satisfied. The gradual development of Rosie and Aiden's romance, both in their personal lives and through their collaborative writing, was beautifully crafted and kept me thoroughly engaged.
conclusion: This book is a delightful rom-com that made me rethink my stance on the enemies-to-lovers trope. The witty banter, relatable characters, and creative structure made it an unputdownable read. Despite a few moments that required suspension of disbelief, the story was heartwarming, hilarious, and thoroughly enjoyable.

- **Initial Interest and Expectations:**  
  I saw this book all over TikTok and Instagram and just had to read it. I love a romance with a bit of academic rivals and enemies-to-lovers trope, especially with a mysterious guy. The fact that the main character loves romance and is a Taylor Swift fan made me even more intrigued. After learning that *Not in My Book* is Katie Holt's first work, I was curious about her writing style and whether I would enjoy the story.  

- **Overall Enjoyment and Pacing:**  
  This book was perfect for me. I loved it so much that I had to stop myself several times to avoid finishing it in one go. I was completely invested in Rosie and Aiden's story. The story was sweet, and while a lot of it was quite cliché, that’s probably what made me love it so much.  

- **Plot and Predictability:**  
  The plot was a bit predictable for me, but I didn’t mind because it really fit into the story. I can see why others might not have enjoyed it as much as I did, but I’m a huge fan of comforting rom-coms, so it worked perfectly for me.  

- **Character Development:**  
  I loved Rosie as the main character. She wanted to live a romance while acknowledging that romance books aren’t reality. She was both a dreamer and a realist, and she had her flaws, which she didn’t try to hide. Aiden is the typical love interest—a bit grumpy but with a soft spot, which I found endearing.  

- **Audiobook Narration:**  
  It was a pleasure to listen to the story. Frankie Corzo did an amazing job narrating it. Sometimes, I don’t like it when women try to sound deeper when voicing male characters, but Frankie did it in a way that didn’t make me cringe. I’ll definitely look out for more audiobooks narrated by her.  

- **Acknowledgments:**  
  Thank you to NetGalley and RBmedia for this Audio-ARC! I can’t wait for Katie Holt’s future projects!  

**Conclusion:**  
This book was a delightful, comforting rom-com that perfectly matched my tastes. While the plot was predictable, the clichés and charming characters made it an enjoyable read. The audiobook narration was excellent, and I’m excited to see what Katie Holt writes next.  

**Rating Scores:**  
(No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.)
